Adieu, sweet poesy, adieu, my lyre;</br>Far other calls must now divide my life;</br>See justice beckons from her awful seat,</br>Midst crowds of subtle managers of strife.
She tells me, ye are triflers light and vain;</br>And tho' ye may not misbecome the youth,</br>When manhood sows his seeds upon the brow,</br>Should cede to reason and her sister truth.
She points to where her darling Alfred stands,</br>Bids my researches his designs pervade:</br>And, wrapt in awe and admiration view,</br>How deep by wisdom her foundation's laid.
Farewel then simple Geoffrey, favour'd Pope,</br>My gentle Edmund, and my tutor Young;</br>Farewel, my much-lov'd Shakespear</br>Farewel to all that wit or fancy sung.
Ye triflers of my youth, too long ye've reign'd;</br>Now sager authors shall supply your place:</br>Amidst the first see Good-man Hale advance,</br>Reflection's son, with slow and solemn pace.
Hail rev'rend Coke!  law's first-born dearest child,</br>Thou ever shalt my most attention claim;</br>Hail honest Salkeld, Ventris, Littleton,</br>"Cum multis al'," too tedious now to name.
With reverence I'll mark each sacred page,</br>Mark how this circumstance with that agrees;</br>While deep-read Harrison, good-natur'd man,</br>Shall name the offices, their clerks, and fees.
And if perchance bewilder'd in a maze,</br>Far from the right my footsteps devious stray,</br>The letter'd Coke, the student's ablest friend,</br>Will kindly point and put me in the way.</br>
